>>18864584
OK, I've strained the stock through a fine mesh strainer, let it a cool a bit, and then put it into these containers. I'm not quite finished with it yet, however.

Even using two fine mesh strainers, there is still some sediment in the stock. It's not too big of a deal, but after chilling the stock will set like Jell-O, and all the fine sediment will have sunk to the bottom. The last step will be to scrape that sediment off.

Also, if you wanted to, you could scrape any remaining fat off, as it will rise to the top.

I'll be back in a couple of hours!

posts.com:
>>18864655
Notes I've collected from different stock threads on /ck/
General advice: always keep it around a low simmer. When it gets up to a boil is when it gets cloudy. You can roast things in the oven for a different flavor. Get a good sense of what works for stock (parsnips, onions, celery) and what doesn't (cauliflower, potatoes). Look up recipes but know you can just use them as references. Make your life easier and put the peppercorns, etc. in a tea bag, the kind used for loose leaf. Also, you can save scraps in the freezer. Mushroom stems are one of my favorite things to add.

literally just boil meat and aromatics, skim the protein skuzz off the top as it cooks, and strain it with a fine mesh sieve at the end

Very lightly coat your bones and veg in a couple of tablespoons of tomato paste, roast or brown them in a pan for deeper flavor, go easy on the salt, and don't go too nuts with fennel unless you REALLY dig the anise flavor. Mushrooms also make a nice addition

Bones and veg have different peak extraction times, start with bones only and after 1-2 hours then add your veg. Roast your bones/trimmings and vegetables, separately, on two parchment-lined sheet trays - at 425F until they are as brown as you want them - especially the chicken bones. The vegetables will likely cook faster than the chicken bones so they are on a separate tray.


Gravy recipe:
Cook some flour in the pan juices. If you don't have enough pan juice and the flour isn't wet enough add some butter. Then gradually add water while whisking. Season with some salt and pepper and some soy sauce. Simple as.
I usually spatchcock a chicken and roast it on a bed of rosemary and garlic, and cover it in a butter rub. Then when it comes gravy time there's some rosemary leaves left in the pan and I'll leave a few cloves of garlic which break up under the whisk.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18861195
Didn’t drink until I was 17, at the after party to my high school ball (I guess burgers would call it prom). Then I got the taste for it.
Was fine for 2 years, alcoholic for 3, fine for another 3, alcoholic for another 3, and now I’m starting to clean up my act for my job. I know people here won’t sympathise or believe me, but my life has improved immensely in the last year through slow tapering.
I’m down to moderately drinking once a week, which is much better than being heavily dependant every day. It just took very small things like dropping a % per vol here and there, and buying slightly less every time you go to the shop.
I recently got back my taste for alcohol for the first time in god knows how long. I actually crave a good beer for the taste, or a good bourbon on the rocks.

tl;dr alcoholism sucks but you can still beat it by being smart. But I ain’t gonna blame you if you don’t want to, it’s your choice.

>>18838977
Those products aren't even available in the Old World, it's just the diaspora community struggling with americanized hedonistic decadence, same thing goes for all the Eastern Christians. Only Ethiopians don't have this problem from what I've seen.
From a Greek Orthodox perspective, as far as fasting goes, you either try to eat fast-appropriate food with greater or lesser effort, or you don't even try to fast. The religious rule of fasting exists to build character, primarily temperance and humility. Outside monastic communities it is not a strict law and more of an ideal, and for laymen it is usually considered enough to simply try your best. Not to get into the finer details, but there is also a strong tradition of vegetarian cooking which exists in order to properly celebrate religious feast days which occur during the fast. The food is meant to taste good, but it is very obviously lighter vegetarian cuisine.
Unlike the Catholics, fish is not licit during the fast (although it is seen as a "less-bad" food, in some places) and in fact in most places, the ideal fast excludes all dietary oils as well - which is by far the least-followed restriction among laymen for obvious reasons.
In this light, it is pretty clear where Beyond Meat and similar products belong. They are, at best, a "less-bad" food like fish, but fake meat products embody principles opposite to the ideal fasting food. The reason there is a "debate" is basically that disinterested laymen who might feel community pressure to fast will try to find loopholes in their daily life, and since the point of the fasting rule is humility, if you are another layman and not a priest it is considered counterproductive to insist and posture over the dietary rule that others are following, for the same reason that you aren't supposed to act prideful over people who don't fast. Still, I think it's pretty clear to everyone that this is a loophole.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Turtle
Squirrel
Shark
Gator

The most recent thing I've made though that I think most people haven't is goose. I feel weird saying that, but the demand has dropped off so much in the last 50 years that it's become prohibitively expensive.
Best tip I can give for that is to take care of the skin, because that's the best part. The meat is good, but the skin is better than any other animal I've tried.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18856953
So far I've had gator, ostrich jerky, kangaroo, bison, duck, rabbit, boar, pheasant, shark, swordfish, elk jerky, quail, bull heart, escargot and housemade goose liver pate from the Culinary Institute of America, goat and also mannish water (goat testicle soup). My favorite out of all was the ground kangaroo burgers, it was like a beautiful steak flavor but the soft buttery texture of a medium rare burger. Meats I want to try are bear, moose, snake, and sea urchin. >Any tips for preparation?
For the roo burgers I got a local brand of game meat sauce, was similar to Worcestersire sauce that I baste a little exyra one each flip, and some coarse salt/cracked pepper. Let the burgs get to room temp and grilled them to medium rare. I did potato bread buns and one with sharp cheddar and one with no cheese..i liked both equally

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18862545
If you can, wait 60-90 minutes between waking up and consuming caffeine. If caffeine is introduced right after waking, the adenosine it antagonizes just builds up and doesn't get bound, which normally causes crashes in the afternoon when the caffeine wears off (which triggers more consumption). If you have caffeine in your system all the way from waking until sleeping, then the adenosine never gets cleared out, and you end up more and more tired when you don't have the caffeine. Thus, golem.

>>18865958
Yeah I remember your posts - what I was trying to get at is, espresso is a hobby and something that you get better at, certain tools and techniques will certainly help with consistency but until you "tune" yourself out as a possible variable, it's hard to know what effect a basket or dosing tool has made vs how much inconsistency you yourself are introducing - I'm not shitting on you or suggesting you're doing anything wrong, but you'll come to realise that the margins are very tight and it takes time to build that "resolution." After a month of getting to know your Pico, there's a pretty good chance that the variation from shot to shot is you more than any of the tools you're using.

Silly example - in my home machine, I'll typically aim for a longer shot, 2.5:1, so 16.5g in, I'll cut it off at 39g and what comes out after I hit the stop button brings it to 41-42g out, targeting 27 seconds. The beans I'm using at the moment, that produces a shot that tastes like slightly boozy raisins and Christmas pudding. If I updose by only 0.5g at the same grind, I'll push out a 2:1 shot in the same time, that tastes like chocolate.

Fine adjustments can create quite large differences even if everything else is the same - not telling you that a decent WDT tool or different baskets aren't worth a look, I'm just suggesting that at this point you might get better value, more learning and more enjoyment out of buying an extra 250g of coffee a week for a month and making more shots

help square a circle for me. i only got into drinking and fiddling around with coffee last year. before that i only rarely drank it if i needed an energy boost
one of my previous memories of coffeee is using the espresso machine at work to make a giant cup of coffee, just stuff the portafilter and run it until a big ~150 ml cup was full. probably ran for close to a minute. and what i remember of its taste was that it was just pretty sour. based on what i've found out about coffee since indicates that if anything, i should have been getting a bitter flavor because of the long extraction time and amount of liquid. sourness is a sign of underextraction right? so how come it was sour?
best explanation i could think of that maybe i was stuffing too much coffee into the portafilter which made it underextract

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18867000
There's a few things it could have been. You stuffed the portafilter so much that it channeled like crazy, giving you an underextracted coffee; your yield was so absurdly high that you diluted it to the point of only leaving sourness or you confused bitterness with sourness, the latter of which is fairly common; or the coffee was ground coarse enough that you didn't get a chance to overextract, which is probably how you would have been able to not choke the machine while over filling the basket. Of those, I suspect it's the first one.

I got dem Goya 47c/bag recently. Bought a bunch. Had them for dinner tonight, actually.
I make them into ham and yellow split pea soup, yellow split pea soup with smoked salmon, split pea hummus and crunchy snacking split peas.
My babymomma is West Indian. She uses them for dal as well as a type of rasam.

Excepting the crunchy snack, we cook split peas twice, once in the pressure cooker and again on the hob. For the hummus, I cook them on the hob until reduced and thick then off the heat and allow to cool then add all the typical hummus ingredients. Works fine with green split peas, too.
For the crunchy ones, I soak them a few hours, drain, pat dry and toss with oil, salt and spices before roasting in a single layer in a hot oven.
We love them shits here.

>>18865826
I prefer the premade batter, specifically Reser's mix, but sure, I can drop a recipe for the batter.

to make the batter:
6 tbs salted butter
3 tbs brown sugar
1-2 tsp cinnamon
1/2 tsp nutmeg, allspice, whatever other spices you like, half as much or a ping of things like anise and cloves, but otherwise to taste

mix and let sit in the fridge a bit before using for better results.

To make the drink:
1.5 tbs of batter
2oz aged rum (personal preference for barbados, Doorly's XO is an easy one. Do not use spiced rum)
6oz or more hot to boiling water

I add a dash of cream to mine. Stir with a cinnimon stick, sprinkle on some nutmeg or cinnamon if you want.

i want this specific exact individual pizza that was made, and eaten, november 20th , 2020. https://i.4cdn.org/ck/1674681354623835.jpg

it got smashed against a wall in the box accidentally
i want this pizza and i don't want any other pizzas
even though it was made and eaten 3 years ago and it was jacked up even at the time
even if i doxxed this pizza i couldn't get the same pizza from the same place because things have changed probably and people come and go
all i have is a picture of it and imagining what it tastes like, but the pizza was gone years before i even knew it existed
it looks pretty similar to most pizzas
but actually, it's one of a kind, it's unique even though it's still just a pepperoni pizza, and between all the pizzas that people in the world have made in the last three years
three years after this pizza was made and eaten, i saw a picture of it, and it became more than just one pizza in the world to me

it became a pizza to the exclusion of other pizzas
for no real reason in particular
the ghost of this pepperoni pizza travelled across time to fixate my hunger long after it's own death, through no effort of its own, on the part of no special intention on the account of anyone involved in this pizzas brief existence
and in such a way... we are more alike than different

rest in pepperonis, pizza that will always could have been, to me, too late, seperated by too wide a gulf of fortune

but you know what? if this pizza had shown up at my doorstep by some careless turn of blind fate... i'd have probably taken it for granted

if god turned the rubicks cube of time and accident and three years ago that pizza had shown up at my door instead of someone elses, i might not have even been hungry that day
that pizza wouldn't have been special to me
so not only is this pizza 3 years since eaten unique to me because of some alignment of the stars, it could have only become the object of desire in this way, and in no other way

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18855620
what an odd thing to think
to think the particular waves of fate that made this pizza so special to me, also made it physically unattainable
but if i had had this very pizza, it would have been just another pizza

there's six pizza places near me but none of them have this pizza. this pizza was gone 3 years ago. i could take a picture of this pizza to somewhere and ask them to make me one just like it, and give them a hundred dollar bill to make it happen

and it still wouldn't be THIS pizza it'd just be an imitation

it's just a pizza that once was. and it's pretty much like most any other pizza. but thats the pizza i want. i heard a story about this pizza

someone said that the pizzaman showed up and fumbled getting it out of the bag, and he tried to stop it from falling for like 10 agonizing seconds, and then kind of caught the box by slapping it against the wall, and he was quite distraught at having ruined the customers pizza but the customer isn't a wound up neurotic wreck, so he just said, well lets look at the damage.

checked it out, and it wasn't that bad. he laughed and said, i'll take it, and paid the price of the pizza to the man. so the pizza i see, the story that brought it to my attention, and the image that caught my attention, it's the product of an accident and a reaction of people far away from me. if the pizza hadn't been fucked up a bit and slammed against a wall, it wouldn't have had a story to tell about it that i'd hear one day

they wouldn't have taken a picture of it when they brought it in, that i'd see one day. and so without the mistake, the fumble, the damage, the story, the accidents, and three years of floating around the back of other peoples minds, i wouldn't be hungry for this pizza in the way that makes me not hungry for other pizzas.

and now, someone's told a second story about this pizza. maybe this will be the last time anyone mentions it, ever.

>>18855578
While at university each dorm building did a group Thanksgiving thing where everyone who wasn't headed home piled into the communal kitchen/eating area to make food and share with each other. We're talking 2 and a half large kitchens (one per floor but only a few people used the 3rd floor kitchen) each with room for 30+ people along with several dozen people out on the green using the shitty park style charcoal grills.
Deciding I want to do something special, I buy a large deep fryer from Walmart and make turkey tempura, various vegetable tempura, chicken tempura, steak tempura, french fries, corn dogs, and anything else anyone brought over to me to deep fry, I deep fry for them.
Yes, I brought a large ass deep fryer to a location with 100+ college age students milling about, with at least half of them drunk.
>"Dude! You can't deep fry turkey! It'll like, explode into a fireball and stuff. I saw it on the tv."
>"That's frozen turkey. And it's the ice and water that does it, not the turkey. This turkey is fully thawed."
>"Ice?"
>"Yes, ice."
>"Dude, that doesn't make sense. How is ice going to make fire?"
>"Google it."
>"So you're saying if I dump this cup of ice, right here, into that deep fryer, it'll somehow make a fireball."
>"Yes."
>"This ice. The ice I have in this cup. Right now."
>"Ye- NO STOP!!!!"
And that's how deep fryers became banned at my university.

>>18855578
This recipe for a South African relish I made last night: https://recipesfromapantry.com/chakalaka/

I think there's both a big typo and a major UK (she's UK-based) vs US difference in some of the ingredients, because she seems to be a decent cook and recipe maker otherwise. But 5 large US carrots is a fucking shitload peeled -- I shredded 2 and it nearly overwhelmed the skillet and the dish, so she must have had a completely different carrot in mind. She doesn't define the peppers -- bell is assumed in other UK recipes so that's what I assume, but that's still a shitload of peppers compared to the onion. Then there's the curry powder, which is unspecified, and I don't know what "mild" means in the UK versus the generic single type in the US. And then the baked beans, hoo boy. She said she made homemade ones, and I had homemade Boston baked beans, and was skeptical so mixed little tastes at the end, and it did not work *at all*. Canned baked beans are quite different, but I don't see any way that would work either, and from her description of the relish it would seem most people just use regular beans, so I don't know what flavor profile she had in mind. Either way, the combination was a disaster. It was odd because normally the UK-US mistranslation is with liquid measurements in baking.

>>18864185
>Big Food and Big Pharma promote diets and supplements
No they don't, moron. For one thing, they don't need to advertise for people to be idiots. For another, fad diets very quickly disrupt supply chain management, and as soon as a large company puts out diet-accomodating products in response, the fad may have died or changed or been cancelled just as easily as it might have gotten more popular and landed that company tons of money for being an early supplier. It's a huge risk for any company to make major changes for a fad unless it has dedicated big parts of its supply change speciifically to cater to fads (and I'm sure by this point in the internet era most have done so -- but it's still a high-risk proposition; for example, to respond to the keto fad companies had to get sourcing for significant amounts of xylitol and shit like that, and get factories retooled to have zero carb contact whatsoever -- even prepping for fast-changing supply lines can't account for the crazy new shit people want, and catering to that supply, spending months building capacity, only to have the fad die within months after you meet capacity, is a huge fucking loss to eat.)

To take an example, big companies *could* cater hard to paleo or raw food diets, but to do so would mean a lot of initial investment and major retooling into a lot of risky bets (like much more perishable food products that they'd have to push onto grocery stores and also lower production costs enough to make them not completely repulsive to consumers), and in the case of raw foods it's a diet that's been a minor fad on and off for centuries and has never gone viral, so doesn't seem like a worthwhile bet. On the other hand, the supply changes needed to go from Atkins to general low-carb to gluten-free and grain-free have been exceedingly minor, so companies have felt felt much safer getting on board with those fads very quickly as they got popular.

>>18862268
genetics and an active and fulfilling social live are the most common correlations with longevity. Diet most definitely plays a major role too.

The Italians and Japanese elders who live super long tend to stay active, not necessarily through exercise but just by being productive, having hobbies, working, and generally interacting with friends or any people. They stay busy and have friends.

You may have also heard that drinking wine is correlated with a longer live, but this may truly be due to those wine drinkers being people who have an active social life and lots of friends who invite them parties where they drink the wine.

The diet aspect of both super old Italians and Japanese can be attributed to their diet being varied and diverse; they don't just eat fish and vegetables and carbs, they eat a variety of meats, fruits and vegetables, and grains, rather than eating the same few things most days. There's a saying in Japanese called "eat the rainbow" which means to try and have a diet consisting of foods that are multicolored like the rainbow. And it cannot be understated that them Japs and Italians LOVE their carbs. rice, bread, pasta, and whatnot. They're also not above desserts, mind you.

When trying to have a healthy diet, the key thing is a varied and diverse diet; not finding the "key superfood" that will supposedly make you healthy. Idiots who fall for fad diets always think there's some secret special ingredient that will heal them and make them healthy and cure all their ailments, and it's always stupid and never supported by science. It's such a reductive way of thinking of diet to think that the key to health is eating some specific food. So while fish is good, do not think of fish as the only thing that makes people healthy. Some fish can be plenty bad for you too anyway, so once again the real key is a diverse diet.

Keto is okay in temporary periods, although imo fasting and a low carb diet is better.

posts.com:
I don't know what the fuck is going on ITT but i actually cook food, and last month i made kimchi.

OP if you have a salinity issue you might not have to worry too much because in many dishes you can just reduce the salt.
You can also add a slice of raw potato to a soup to reduce the salinity, the potato absorbs the salt then simply throw the potato away.

I wouldn't risk trying to desalinisate the kimchi while it's fermenting, part of me thinks you could dip raw potato slices in the liquid for an hour then toss them but honestly if it's your first try at kimchi i wouldn't fool around

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some observations about kimchi:
Most recipes call for way too much carrot, the sourness of home made kimchi will increase for months, everyone lies about the shelf life of kimchi, I don't know how long it's actually good for but my impression is that if the acidity is stable, the temperature is constant, the kimchi remains under the brine it could last more than a year- but before then it will turn into a very sour soup mush. The kimchi i made months ago and put in the fridge it's totally fine, just like my sourkraut.

strong floral fragrance. refreshing green herbal taste, reminds me of mint or lavender maybe? would be great on a hot summer day

>>18861512
if its buds, 5g/100ml 80-85c, 15seconds then either +5 or +15 seconds with each additional steep. buds can get very bitter but i think they do better with longer gongfu steepings.
if its leaves the same but you can use full boiling, but tend to do better with shorter steeps. some people also simmer the leaves in a saucepan for a long time.

i find whites to be the hardest to brew right because they all seem to require different parameters where as black/oolongs/green ect call brew up well with the same parameters i.e all blacks behave the same, all whites behave differently at least for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18861512
>>18862215
You need to full soak the buds to get them to start extracting, which takes a pretty long time. Depending on your preference, you can do a fairly long hard rinse, boiling water for 30s or more depending on how dense your buds are, or you can do a short rinse, 5-10s at with boiling water, then a long brew, say 30s with boiling water. Once the leaves seem soaked through, they'll noticeably extract much faster. Do 10-15s brews here, if your tea is pleasant but thin, use more leaf, I brew with a very high ratio of leaf to water for baihao yinzhen. If it starts to be astringent or develop off flavors, you can do your main brews at around 90C instead. Once the leaves start to thin out, I like to do a single minute long brew, then a five minute brew and end it.

It will depend on the leaves you have, but the basic profile should look like that. Long brew to soak the leaves and get them to open up a bit, successions of much shorter brews, a few long brews. At close to boiling or boiling water, but feel free to lower the temperature if you feel you need to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18862960
A deep-sided cast iron works well. It must be deep enough that the oil comes up to the halfway line of your pieces of chicken. You'll have to flip once. A lot of people do this. The standard 8-10-12" skillets won't work very well for bone-in breasts or thighs. Not deep enough without risking overfilling the oil and spilling, which is a huge mess at best, a fire hazard at worst. They'll work for deboned breasts and thighs, legs, wings, and tendies though. Eyeball your shit and see if it'll work. If not, buy a deep skillet or dutch oven.

The cookware in the picture was a basic set of ceramic coated cookware from the food network that was given to me as a house warming present. They worked fine for a couple of year but they did eventually start to get chips and scratches in the ceramic coat so I started to slowly replace them piece by piece with more “forever cookware” like Allclad, demeyere and le creuset. I still have a small 8” from that original ceramic set that works great for making fried eggs without any sticking. If you need something for the next few years you would be happy with that basic set though. I think it’s only $129 for a 10 piece set.

I've always thought of macro lager drinkers as cigarette smokers while IPA (or just craft beer in general) drinkers are more like cigar smokers. People who smoke cigarettes have their brand, and only want their brand. They don't smoke it because they enjoy the flavor. They just enjoy the act of smoking and have found a brand that hits right for them and will get upset if they have to settle for a different brand. Cigar smokers savor their cigars rather than sucking them down on a 5 minute break, and are always happy to try something new and different. Imagine a couple guys just hanging out and smoking a couple cigars when a couple other guys walk by and are having an argument about whether Camels or Marlboros are better. To the guys smoking the cigars they just think both are shit and it's silly to argue over which turd tastes better. That's what it's like when you're talking about beer and someone chimes in with, "for me it's Coors Banquet".

>>18863686
Appliance repair guy here.
Good thread OP, and good thinking using a dishwasher for cleaning parts, it will clean cast iron gas stove grates nicely. You can even put in the cast iron gas burner parts to wash as well. Be careful of washing the aluminum diffuser plates as those are sensitive to soaps that contain bleach. Also, diffusers have vent holes that can be plugged with debris. After the dishwashing/drying cycle is done put each burner and grate back on and check for proper flame ignition and even flame height. May you have many happy meals!

Seedlip makes nonalcoholic botanical infusions ("gin") and they have partner companies making botanical NA "wines", thus giving NA "martini" recipes. I haven't tried any of it, but the reviews on seedlip are pretty positive, and what makes vermouth vermouth and bitters bitters is botanicals and spices after all, so there's no reason it can't be made NA. https://www.seedlipdrinks.com/en-gb/journal/three-ways-to-make-a-non-alcoholic-martini/

Solmonson & Solmonson ("6 Bottle Bar") have a recipe for a gunpowder liqueur that infuses either gunpowder or lapsang souchong tea in brandy with sugar. Although I'm definitely gonna make that, I want to try lapsang souchong on its own, but it's quite hard to find.

If it's a light rum the basic cocktail is a daiquiri, and if it's a dark rum the basic cocktails are mostly substitutions for whiskeys and aged tequilas in all their classics: so dark rum sour, dark rum old fashioned, dark rum Manhattan, sidecar, etc.

>>18866326
I haven't tried these, but for example when I was looking at Stirrings Blood Orange Bitters (NA), the common review was that it was too weak, and that you'd just need to up the quantity by a significant amount (3x or more?) to get the same effect as a regular alcoholic top-brand bitters. That said, from what people here have said, that just might be what you have to deal with for NA drinking for the time being until demand pushes competition and innovation further.(I can't imagine they couldn't simply distill a glycerine infusion, figuring out the ideal temp and pressure like with anything else).

It doesn't matter so much with bitters -- if you have to use 3x or 10x extra in an OF it still won't affect your drink (you can always reduce the added water or use a 2:1 or agave syrup). And there are several young gin OF recipes, and I've found unaged OF variants in general can be extremely pleasant.

Basically kind of akin to nachos. You generally eat nachos during specific events (like digging into a plate while watching a UFC fight stream on Saturday or watching playoffs, etc). Or if you're craving some at 2pm and a Mexican place nearby makes a good version of them or whatever. But rarely/never would you have them for dinner.

>>18861918
>>18862144
>>18862665
I'm Chinese, these guys are pretty much right. It's certainly not a formal dish; if you went to a Chinese dinner party, it would be very weird if the only dish in the entire meal was baozi. The equivalent is your mom and dad dragging you to a dinner and a family friend's house, and your mom forces you to dress up in a collared shirt, but when you get to the their house, everyone there is in t-shirts and shorts, your friends are laying around playing video games, and dinner will be chili dogs.

That being said, if your families are close enough nobody's gonna care. Baozi are more street food than formal, but there's nothing wrong with having a few as your dinner, just like there's nothing wrong with having a couple hotdogs as a dinner. But just like hotdogs, it's more common to combine them with other stuff. If you're having hotdogs for dinner, why not cook up some burgers, make a pasta salad, and do some fresh cut fries? Same concept applies with boazi; if there's a spread of other Chinese dishes then nobody's gonna question why there are baozi for dinner.

>>18858946
>people live in apartments now, they don't have cellars any more
>no cellars, no ageing bottles of wine
>winemakers make wines that should be drank immediately as a result
>climate change causes grapes to ripen too soon, making them bold/loud without personality (wine regions became far less important)
>people with money aren't interested in discovering great wines any more, they just want to impress/dominate their peers on Instagram
>You can't taste on Instagram. It's the very definition of bad taste and arrogance
>winemaking has improved immensely over the past 2 decades, most/all decanting (getting rid of the sediment) is done on the farm. We can open, pour and close bottles without losing quality now.
>On the contrary we actually get far better wines. If only we had this tech a century ago.
If you still got a bottle from the early 80s or before/really love those wines, you really need to decant. Decanting = where you get rid of the sediment that forms in a bottle.

Aeration = where you allow your good/better/best wine to take on oxygen, bringing it back to life. Opening the bottle an hour (or 2) beforehand, pouring the bottle into a receptacle and/or glasses, and decanting all provide aeration.

That's why decanting is hipster garbage. Usually just opening the bottle beforehand is enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18861647
I don't follow an exact recipe, it's a pretty simple dish but this is my go to:

Cook 1/2 stick of butter and 1 lb of ground breakfast sausage (sage flavor is best), do not drain, once the meat begins to brown, add flour and stir, keep adding until all the liquid is absorbed then cook for a few minutes extra, then slowly add in whole milk until it gets soupy (runs off a spoon), then simmer on low heat until it's not soupy (sticks to spoon). Season with salt, pepper, garlic powder, onion powder.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Since biscuits and gravy always seems to confuse or repulse our friends across the pond, allow me to once again explain.
What you guys call biscuits, we call cookies. Our biscuits are sort of like scones, pic related. Pretty much just flour and butter. They're usually fairly dense, so we eat them with some sort of sauce, gravy or spread, even if it's just butter.
The gravy is a very simple sausage gravy, it's pretty much just ground pork with all the fat, flour, milk, and the seasonings being the most important part. I keep it simple with just black pepper and sage.
Biscuits & gravy is a super cheap poverty meal that's become a comfort food staple for most of the US over the decades. Goes best topped with some runny eggs, I prefer mine over easy. A couple dashes of hot sauce, and it's perfect. Sometimes I like to get fancy and double down on the sloppa with some chili and sauteed mushrooms & onions, maybe even some sharp cheddar or pepperjack.
A fantastic sloppy meal to soak up all the ridiculous amounts of alcohol you've consumed in the past 6 hours. Definitely not something to eat often though, it's clearly unhealthy.

I love biscuits and gravy. I grew up with a mom that always used a packet mix to make gravy along with jimmy dean sausage and she used prepackaged biscuits. When I make it I usually use 1lb sausage, preferably sage. If I don't have sage sausage I'll add sage seasoning. I cook it in the skillet, add 3/4c flour, then cook the rawness out for a while. Then I add 2c milk. Then when it's gravy like I add 2c more. Then 2c more then s&p a small splash of Worcestershire and it's done. That's it. I tried red pepper flakes before but it was unnecessary. I usually use store bought biscuits but half the time I do make my own. It's not hard just annoying having to clean up the flour but since buying a dough scraper it's a lot easier.
Also when I was dogsitting for my aunt I tried picrelated and I fucking love it. It's like how canned asparagus is really good but not the same as fresh asparagus which is also really good. It's just good ok I like the libby's shit the homemade shit and how my mom makes it. I just like gravy. I also will use leftover sausage gravy and just top my eggs with it.

>I am in Canada and real Mexicans are few and far between. Please teach me about good Mexican food so I can impress my friends and family.
Here's a no bullshit recipe for mexican shredded beef, that you can turn into soup, tacos, sandwiches, enchiladas. Whatever the fuck you want. If you have a pressure cooker, that also works.
You need:
32 oz of beef stock
1 4 pound roast
1 yellow onion
1 tomato
1 can of chipotle peppers (optional for heat)
Salt
Garlic powder
Cumin powder
>Get a 4 lb roast (beef)
>Cut into 4 or 5 equal chunks
>Season each piece with salt and garlic powder
>marinate overnight (this is important don't skip this part)
Next day
>heat up large, deep skillet
>add half a stick of butter (salted or non-salted, doesn't matter)
>dice half a yellow onion and one large tomato
>throw in pan
>mash the tomato while it's cooking
>add some salt and a tablespoon of cumin powder
>mix until the tomatos and onions are kind of like a paste
>add 16 oz of beef stock
>let it simmer for like 5 minutes
>add the rest of the beef stock
>let it simmer for another 20 minutes
>throw the roast chunks in a slow cooker or a pressure cooker
>throw the soup you just made on top of it
>add Half a TABLESPOON of cumin powder (1.5 tablespoons total, trust me don't fuck this part up)
>slow cook that shit for like 3 hours on high heat
>take out the roast
>shred it
>put it back in
>slow cook it for another hour
This shit will impress anybody. You can add chipotle peppers if you want heat, too.
You can also just add one or two vegetables that you like and eat it as soup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think making authentic ramen recipes is overrated. Still delicious, those authentic Japanese recipes, but I think it's more satisfying to build your ramen to your personal liking while still maintaining the elements that make it Japanese ramen.

Traditional Japanese ramen recipes use kombu and bonito fish flakes as the base for the broth, and while that is delicious, you can still achieve the savory umami base broth with other things and achieve a result that most people couldn't tell the difference from.

other sources of umami besides kombu and bonito flakes:
>yeast extract or "marmite"
>fish sauce
>soy sauce
>dried salted or canned anchovies
>red miso
>dried mushrooms
>savory/umami seasoning blends (which often contain some yeast extract and dried mushroom)
>MSG obviously
>any meat-based stock like chicken stock or beef stock
>bouillon paste or bouillon stock cubes
In fact, many store-bought stock and bouillon paste/cubes contain some yeast extract specifically for the reason that it tastes like meat. Meat imitation products usually will use a combination of yeast extract and MSG to achieve fake beef and chicken flavors without any animal products, so that stuff alone is powerful.

And then there's the noodles. Check the ingredients. If your noodles aren't made with both wheat and alkaline salts, they aren't really ramen noodles. Alkaline salts or minerals may include potassium carbonate, potassium bicarbonate, magnesium sulfate, magnesium chloride, calcium chloride. I've heard you can boil even plain pasta noodles in water with baking soda to get a similar texture to ramen noodles but I have not tried that. I feel like baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) would just end up making the noodles taste kind of soapy.

Soy sauce is a must in ramen broth, even if it's not shoyu ramen.

>wish I knew how to make good tonkatsu
take a bunch of pigs feet cut in half and a chicken carcass or two (depending on your stock pot size) and wash them well
if you want a light end product you also need to blanch these first and wash them again while removing anything brown like blood/organ parts left behind/dark bone marrow, but this only affects look, not taste and is a pain in the ass to do properly.
put them in the stockpot along with rough chopped onions, garlic, ginger, leeks and spring onions (keep the green parts for adding to the finished soup) and mushrooms. if you're on a budget then just onions & garlic. some people heavily brown the vegetables first, some don't. it's up to you, your choice.
bring it to a high heat boil, skim off the scum, use paper towels to get any that has stuck to the pot itself
give it about 20 minutes and get it down to a gentle simmer/slow boil
how long you leave it is up to you, but 4 hours is your minimum, 6 hours is where I'd stop. Restaurants might go 8/10/12 hours because they're leaving shit overnight but you get diminishing returns and after 12 you're just wasting gas/electricity.
strain and serve with noodles and meat.
if you really feel it necessary, add soy sauce, salt & pepper, sesame oil, fresh garlic or chilli to taste.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18855845
>Is anyone going to share recipes
look further up the page there's at least one post with a guide
>why pig feet
because they're the cheapest, least used part of a pig, and they have a significant amount of gelatin, which helps set & provide body to a stock.
other cheap cuts like pork shoulder are still much more useful as eating parts so you wouldn't use them for stock, and the other offcuts are usually more expensive because they will get used for dog treats (eg ears, hock, tail)
>Is it just pig feet or do you add other stuff too
alliums (garlic, leek, shallot, onions) and mushroom.
in terms of other meat parts, the common ones are chicken, duck or turkey carcasses, necks & wingtips and feet (with nails and ammonia stained parts clipped off), and pig tails
>why is it boiled instead of simmered unlike other stocks?
it's basically the same thing. most of the time it comes down to if the person cooking wants to watch it closely while it boils, because you then top up the stock to keep the bones underwater, or if you want a large portion and not have to watch it as closely, so you just simmer it less rapidly. personally I don't think there's much difference between a long simmer and a more rapid boiling over 4+ hours.

You can do tonkotsu with just pork, but you might find it 'dirty' tasting, that's why people add chicken bones also. As for the exact parts, as long as you have enough bones AND enough skin+cartilage, from whatever animal, you're good to go. I personally like making stock with 2:1 pork to chicken matter, with pork being feet/spines/hip joints, and chicken being backs/feet/wings in a pinch. Plus also you add ginger+scallions+optionally carrot and/or napa.

The difference between rolling boil and slow simmer is that slow simmer makes a clear soup, while rolling boil emulsifies the fat into the soup (which you can do with a blender at the end anyway), producing milky soup in the end. Depends what you're going after.

Also one of the last bowls I made :))

>>18855845
My ramen broth is just regular all-purpose stock I make (just some bones and meat of chicken or beef or both chicken and beef simmered with a basic mirepoix of onion, carrot, and celery) that can be used in most soups, some broth made by soaking dried mushrooms in hot water for 20 minutes (or just add the dried mushrooms straight to the stock), soy sauce, oyster sauce, garlic, and sometimes red miso and ginger if I'm feeling like it.

You can also just use regular store-bought chicken broth and add soy sauce, garlic, and ginger to it and it will taste pretty identical to Japanese ramen broth.

Toppings can include dried seaweed, any meat you like and any vegetables you like but green onions are common. Also there's eggs. You can boil an egg for 7 to 8 minutes for a medium boiled egg.

And ramen noodles obviously.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18864671
Those are some very oxidized potatoes.

They make a product that can help fix this called Nature Seal. Or, you can make your own version. It is Sodium Ascorbate AKA Ascorbic Acid Salt. It needs to be made into a solution to soak the potatoes. To make your own, mix 2 TBSP Ascorbic Acid and 2 TBSP Sodium Bicarbonate (Baking Soda) in 1 Gallon of water. Mix thoroughly. It will get a little foamy as the reaction occurs. Once it is fully mixed and neutralized, soak your shredded potatoes in the solution, completely covered, for 10-15 minutes.

The Sodium Ascorbate will neutralize the enzymes that cause browning. This works for apples and pears as well.

Also, as a general rule when making hashbrowns, it's really important to remove as much liquid from the potatoes as possible. Whether or not you use a Sodium Ascorbate solution, it will help to squeeze as much liquid out of the shredded potatoes as you possibly can. The drier they are, the better your hashbrowns will turn out.

Also, if you don't have Ascorbic Acid (also known as Vitamin C) you can use lemon juice. Just double the volume listed above. This sometimes does not work as well, however, but lemons do contain quite a lot of Ascorbic Acid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18859365
>>18862418
>>18862471
Ostrich feed conversion ratio (FCR) is about 5:1 now and at the pace of research will probably get to 4:1, while beef is 15:1 and the hyper-optimized chicken is less than 2:1.

The FCR equivalent (inverse of NFEI -- Net Feed Efficiency Index) for chicken egg laying alone is a little more than 2:1 (at lease 2.2 was what I saw online as the target threshold at which an egg farm would be competitive, so the average efficiency of a farm is probably significantly higher). In maturity an ostrich lays an average around 50 eggs per year, while a small-farm chicken can lay an average of 200. I can't find the FCR equivalent for ostrich eggs.

So if required land area and labor are not a major issue, and not accounting for methane emissions (though they would have a ceiling by the amount of feed eaten, so it couldn't possibly be more than cattle), then ostrich farms are currently (pending future research) about as sustainable a choice of protein as, say, pork.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18852546
Well for starters what you described is "flavoured" wine and would not be able to sell for anywhere near what most quality wines would. The flavors developed through fermentation versus added fruit concentrate taste completely different when it comes to balancing the flavors and acids of the resulting beverage.
>herculean effort
Adjusting fermentation temperatures and using certain yeast isn't as "herculean" as you may think. You have to do those things when making wine regardless, same with inert vessel and/or oak fermentation, fining, clarification and bottle ageing.
Unless you're the Wagner family of course. Caymus Cabernet is basically grape juice + megepurple. But anyone who likes that wine is an utter pleb beyond the plebs who buy $15 generic California AVA shit on the bottom shelf.

>>18852818
Zinfandel can be nice. Fetzer's is okay-ish, for not even double the price you get really good stuff. See to keep it around 13% abv.
Also check out Shiraz (or Syrah) and Sangiovese. Many people like them.
If you want to have something exotic (I assume you're from the US), try to find a Lagrein (I see they're grown in Cali as well).
For guests that prefer whites, add a Sauvignon Blanc (dry) and Muscatel (sweet).

>>18851457
In April 1991, rumors began circulating in Black neighborhoods that the beverage was laced with a secret ingredient that would sterilize black men.[2] The beverage quickly earned the nickname "Tropical Fanticide." The rumors claimed that the Ku Klux Klan was actually bottling the product and using the low price to attract poor citizens.[3] Similar unfounded rumors about Klan involvement periodically have plagued the Church's Fried Chicken chain and Snapple soft drinks.[3]

Later that year the rumor spread rapidly and provoked violence in many city neighborhoods. Attacks occurred on delivery trucks and storekeepers who stocked Tropical Fantasy. Due to these rumors and rising suspicions, sales of the beverage plummeted by 70%.[citation needed]

Investigations found the claims to be as preposterous.[3] Sales recovered only after an extensive public relations campaign that included then-New York City Mayor David N. Dinkins, (who was Black) drinking a bottle of the soda for television news cameras.[3]

By mid June 1991 the attacks had stopped and the sales had rebounded, but the dark rumors about Tropical Fantasy were not forgotten. Even today, the rumors are still circulating. Many young teenagers refer to the beverages as "Bummies" and "Nutties", mainly due to the rumor that it kills sperm. This is not however limited to the Tropical Fantasy beverage. Other beverages such as "City Club", "Top Pop", and "C&C", are ridiculed in exactly the same way.

I have a funny idea for a thread where I make rice over a wood fire outdoors. I just gotta bite the bullet on a decent hagame at this point and keep an eye out for a final top tier one.

Here's a cool little trick you can use to improve your rice.

Binchotan, or bamboo charcoal. You can put a piece of the charcoal in your rice cooker and it purifies the water maling a cleaner tasting rice.

If you leave the charcoal pieces in tap water overnight it also makes noticeably nicer tasting water. It's quite remarkable the difference it makes.

Then you do a final rinse, soak, and cook with the purified water.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18858059
If you eat rice regularly, the time and energy required to cook it stovetop add up. On the stove you've got to wait for a boil, then set timers to kill the flame and tend to it. With a rice cooker it's just wash, then add rice and water to cooker. You can leave the house even. I've been trying to lower my overall food cost lately, and with a rice cooker I make rice more often, which lowers my average food cost, while being much easier to prepare than making bread or homemade pasta.

Lately I've been really into the idea of automating my cooking as much as feasible, using minimal dishes and making my own freezer food. That way cooking (and cleaning up afterward) whatever takes nearly zero effort, and so I eat cheaper/healthier, don't go out to eat so much, and enjoy cooking more (it doesn't feel like a chore when I want to cook something more laborious).

posts.com:
Here is my recipe. I made asian chicken stock, so I went with asian flavors.

Maybe 1.5 cups of chicken
300ml of semi reduced chicken stock
A pinch of five spice powder
3 pieces of star anise
A pinch of ginger powder
2 tsp of doubanjiang
Half an onion
1 stick of butter

Saute thinly sliced onions for a little
Add doubanjiang and cook for a couple mins
Add everything
Simmer gently until all liquid is gone.

Also rendering 16lbs of very nice beef tallow. The good stuff found around the kidneys.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Okay, well I think it's done. Added a bit of white pepper, soy sauce, and salt to season. It came out absolutely delicious. Sweet, very very savory, flavor is a little like a chinese sausage, but less sharp.

Spreadable and creamy. Toasting some bread. To really enjoy it.

posts.com: Any vegetarians here? I want to stop eating meat, but I'm afraid that it will fuck up my health

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Vegetarian for 10 years (+ 2-3 years before that when I was a young teen) you should do it OP! Dont worry about it fucking up your health just take a multivitamin (look for special vegetarian ones that dont use animals). Important things to ensure youre getting that might be difficult without meat is iron, and B vitamins (and maybe zinc I wanna say). B vitamins are a big deal, but you can actually get it from algae! If you like seaweed I highly recommend incorporating it into your diet plus its tasty af and virtually zero calories. Iron just eat lots of nuts/seeds, beans, and dark greens. If you like greens try using olive oil when making a salad or dish with them since it helps with nutrient absorbtion. Also check out nutritional yeast for b vitamins its also a nice thing to add for some umami to food or for a cheese alternative if you ever wanna vegan mode. Also getting enough protein is important so again nuts and beans and also stuff like tofu and seitan and eggs if you eat them (imo can be ethically consumed if locally sourced from someone you know is treating chickens properly). Vegan meat and cheese replacements have come a long way in recent years but definitely try to limit your use of them a bit, theyre kinda like junk food most of the time and easy to fall back on over a proper balanced diet. Cheers and good luck anon ily

>>18859721
Going vegetarian is easy and I did it for 5 years before going fully vegan for the last year. It's not hard at all to replace meat with things like eggs and tofu. If you think it would be, try frying up an egg with whatever seasonings you usually put on meat instead, and then try a piece of meat without any seasonings. You'll quickly realize how much you really only care about the seasonings you out on meat and not really the meat itself. If you're interested in going vegan or more in depth cooking instructions, go to veganbootcamp.com and try the 30 day challenge. It will show you the what, how, and why of cooking with plants over animals.
If you're worried at all about nutrition, just eat your greens, take b12, and vitamin D. That's all that would be hard to get in a plant based diet.

Vegetarian for three or four years, recently went back to small amounts of fish and cured meats. There are much more experienced people to give you nutritional advice, I will just say, do not fall into the trap of trying to recreate your favorite non-vegetarian foods with 'alternative' products. They are ridiculously overpriced and overprocessed and most are still shitty compromises in terms of flavor. Focus on the stuff you like that is already vegetarian (pasta, rice & beans, etc) and dishes where you can remove the meat without missing much. Tofu is decent occasionally, especially in Asian dishes where it can be a key ingredient even when there's meat, but don't rely on soy protein to carry you. Your mentality is as important if not more so than your grocery list.

>>18859721
It used to be conventional wisdom, and even taught in health classes at school, that you should consult a Doctor before making any major dietary changes. This is because, in addition to different people having different nutritional needs from habit and genetics, it's possible to have underlying conditions that can make some dietary changes really dangerous.

Most people subconsciously eat what their body is telling them to some degree. If you had, for instance, a glycemia issue, and had been naturally eating a lot of carbs to balance things out, if you started a low-carb diet it can be really dangerous for your health.

If you don't have access to a Doctor, my advice would be to make minor dietary changes and monitor how you feel. With vegetarianism, I would maybe start just by reducing the amount of meat you're eating, instead of completely removing it from your diet.

Also, I wouldn't really listen to anyone on /ck/.

>>18859722
Vegetarian for 10+ years (ovo-lacto) and have never had to take supplements (and I have asked my doctor specifically about iron etc. regarding my vegetarianism during physicals and bloodwork). Generally the body regulates its metals and vitamins pretty well if you're eating a variety of modern foods, so I really wouldn't obsess over it too much if you're eating a variety and cooking something fresh from time to time.

From my own experience it was not stressful at all to go veg when I wasn't strict about starting it and I was eating with a friend who was veg and could tell me things to look out for (but who also didn't get on my case when I ignored her in the early days -- fuck it, I'll eat gelatin and beef stock and anything a host offers). It was also easier when I bought stuff for myself fresh at the grocery store and compared price per pound, and it was obvious how much more expensive using meat in my meals would be than beans, various substitutes, or even just veg + whole grains + butter and eggs.

As a tip, if you're looking to cut down on cow's milk for environmental or other reasons then just sub soy milk for your cooking -- same protein and fat content, unlike other substitutes. Fuck the fads and fuck inefficient protein-poor almonds. (For drinking plain or mixing in drinks, drink whatever tastes best and fuck health advice, excepting anything in excess of course.)

Otherwise I can't speak for everyone because I cook for myself all the time and (used to) exercise a shitload.

>>18858405
different ingredients and cooking techniques
>indian curry
garlic, ginger, onions, many spices like cumin, coriander, cardamom, cinnamon, turmeric, black cardamom, pepper, anise, etc
onions and spices are fried in oil, then tomatoes are added and its thickened with yogurt, cream, ground nuts, or coconut milk in southern cuisine
>thai curry
lemongrass, galangal, shallot, cilantro root, shrimp paste, fish sauce, soy sauce, occasionally some spices like cumin & coriander
aromatics are ground into a paste and fried in a little coconut milk, then more coconut milk and other liquids are added and simmered

thai curry tastes more east asian because of the fermented sauces and isnt as thick as indian curry

Mostly winged it but I guess

>Rinse rice

>Add chopped garlic and jalapenos
>Season with salt, pepper, cumin, smoked paprika and ground coriander
>Add Chorizo

>Once rice is cooked remove from the heat and let sit for 10 - 15 minutes

>Top with a fried egg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18863876
Get a wide pan.
Saute an assortment of vegetables.
Add some protein, chicken, pork, whatever, eggs won't work here.
Add some spices you want.
Brown the protein on each side.
Add rice, don't rinse it if you want the final sauce to be more creamy, stir constantly for 30 seconds to 1 minute.
Add a cooking liquid that isn't too thick, a combination of stock, wine, tomato puree, water or any other liquid could work, depending on what you like, milk probably won't work but you do you, add the recommended amount in the rice package.
Cover the pan and lower the heat.
It should take depending on how high or low you go around 20 minutes, just check after 15 minutes or so.
It goes without saying but salt to taste.

>>18863917
Most vegetables are good for over a week out of the fridge, even at 40 celsius room temperature during the day. I know this from experience. Leafy greens might only last a few days, and the florets on brocolli will turn yellow within a week. Cover them all with a net to keep the fliea off. Meat will only be good on day of purchase, so you'll want plenty of canned fish. There's also powdered milk, which doesn't taste great, but is handy.
